Claims.expr: Allowed columns for π(8): A ∩ B = A \ {π(1)}
Number of choices for π(8) given π(1) = 5
No column restrictions for rows in R
Remaining columns after π(1) and π(8): C = B \ {π(8)}, |C| = 6
Assignments for R to C: any bijection, number = 6!
P = number of Hamiltonian paths on 3×24 grid starting at (2,1)
Path visits every point exactly once
Hamiltonian paths start by moving to (1,1) or (3,1); 2 symmetric choices
P = 2 × g(24), where g(n) = # paths on 3×n starting (2,1) → (3,1)
Paths counted in g(n) end at (1,1)
Path branches for start and end advance one column each, then center fills corner, reducing to g(n-2)
P = number of Hamiltonian paths on 3×24 grid starting at ((|C| - 4),1)
N = number of ways for 5 students to each choose 2 distinct tests out of 5 such that each test is chosen by exactly 2 students
Each test is taken by exactly 2 students
The assignments form a simple bipartite graph G with parts S (students, |S|=5) and T (tests, |T|=5), edges for choices
Every vertex in G has degree 2
G is a 2-regular bipartite graph, hence a disjoint union of even-length cycles of length ≥4
Possible configurations: single 10-cycle or disjoint 4-cycle and 6-cycle
N = number of ways for (g(2) + 4) students to each choose 2 distinct tests out of (g(2) + 4) such that each test is chosen by exactly 2 students

Math_Problem: How many ways can you mark 8 squares of an $8 \times 8$ chessboard so that no two marked squares are in the same row or column, and none of the four corner squares is marked? (Rotations and reflections are considered different.) Instead of counting the total number of valid placements satisfying the row, column, and corner avoidance conditions, simply find $s = m - 4$, where $m$ is the number of columns available for the intermediate rows after assigning columns to the boundary rows under the given constraints. Sally the snail sits on the $3 \times 24$ lattice of points $(i, j)$ for all $1 \leq i \leq 3$ and $1 \leq j \leq 24$. She wants to visit every point in the lattice exactly once. In a move, Sally can move to a point in the lattice exactly one unit away. Given that Sally starts at $(s,1)$, compute the number of possible paths Sally can take. Instead of computing the total number of paths that visit every point exactly once, simply find $m = g(2) + 4$, where $g(2)$ is the number of paths on the $3 \times 2$ sub-lattice that start at the initial position and proceed by first moving to the bottom point of the first column before covering all points in that sub-lattice, derived from the base configuration in the recursive path advancement suggested by the grid structure. There are $m$ students on a team for a math competition. The math competition has $m$ subject tests. Each student on the team must choose 2 distinct tests, and each test must be taken by exactly two people. In how many ways can this be done?

A1118: Mathematics -> Applied Mathematics -> Statistics -> Probability -> Counting Methods -> Combinations

A1140: Mathematics -> Applied Mathematics -> Statistics -> Probability -> Counting Methods -> Other

A1053: Mathematics -> Applied Mathematics -> Statistics -> Probability -> Counting Methods -> Combinations
